@metadata.goal: Students can identify unit fractions in real-world contexts

steps.dialogue: Emma cut a sandwich into 6 equal pieces and ate 1 piece.
Click the fraction that shows how much Emma ate.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count how many pieces the sandwich was cut into.
[event:pulse_all_sections]Let's think about this together. Count all the pieces in the sandwich, then see how many Emma ate. That gives you the fraction.

[event:count_sections_sequentially][event:highlight_eaten_vs_total]Here, I'll walk you through this. The sandwich was cut into pieces. Let's count them: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. That's 6 total pieces. Emma ate 1 piece. So she ate 1 out of 6, which is 1/6. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: You got it! One piece out of six is one-sixth.

@metadata.goal: The student can shade one part to represent a unit fraction

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle bar divided into 6 equal parts.
Shade one part to show [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction].

step.dialogue: Check how many parts you shaded.

events.name: pulse_sections
events.description: All sections pulse briefly to draw attention to counting

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections]You're working on it. We need exactly 1 part shaded to show [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. Count your shaded sections.

events.name: shade_single_section
events.description: Animated demonstration shading exactly one section with counting overlay showing '1 out of 6'

step.dialogue: [event:shade_single_section]This can be tricky, so let's do it together. [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]One sixth[/fraction] means 1 part out of 6 total parts. Watch as I shade just one section here. See? That's [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. You showed [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] perfectly.

@metadata.goal: The student can express equal parts using unit fraction notation

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle divided into 3 equal parts. One part is shaded.
Which fraction shows the shaded portion?

step.dialogue: Count the shaded parts and the total parts.

events.name: highlight_shaded_section
events.description: The shaded section pulses to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_shaded_section]Let's think about this together. The top number shows shaded parts, the bottom shows total parts. How many are shaded?

events.name: count_sections_sequentially
events.description: Each section lights up sequentially as it's counted, with the shaded section highlighted in a different color

events.name: show_fraction_labels
events.description: Animated labels appear showing '1 shaded' pointing to shaded section and '3 total' spanning all sections

step.dialogue: [event:count_sections_sequentially][event:show_fraction_labels]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Count the shaded parts: just 1. Count all the parts: 1, 2, 3. So we have 1 shaded out of 3 total. That's [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction]. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! One out of three parts is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction].

@metadata.goal: The student can count the total number of equal parts in a whole

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle divided into equal parts. Some parts are shaded blue, some red, and some aren't shaded at all.
How many equal parts make up the whole rectangle? Count all the parts, whether they're shaded or not.

prompt.text: Select the total number of parts

step.dialogue: Count all the parts in the rectangle, not just the shaded ones.

events.name: highlight_all_sections
events.description: All sections of the rectangle pulse sequentially to emphasize counting all parts

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_all_sections]You're working on it. Count every section in the whole rectangle - shaded and unshaded. How many sections do you see total?

events.name: sequential_count_overlay
events.description: Animated overlay showing numbers 1-6 appearing sequentially above each section as they're counted

step.dialogue: [event:sequential_count_overlay]Let's count together. Watch as I point to each section: one, two, three, four, five, six. See? Six equal parts make up the whole rectangle. Some are shaded, some aren't, but they all count. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! Six equal parts make the whole, no matter how many are shaded.

@metadata.goal: The student can count the total number of equal parts in a whole

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle bar divided into equal parts.
How many equal parts make up the whole bar?

prompt.text: Select the number of equal parts

step.dialogue: Count the sections in the bar again.

events.name: highlight_sections_sequential
events.description: Each section of the bar highlights briefly in sequence from left to right

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_sections_sequential]Let's look more carefully. Count each section one at a time from left to right across the whole bar.

events.name: count_sections_with_labels
events.description: Animated counting demonstration: each section highlights in sequence with numbered labels (1, 2, 3, 4, 5) appearing above each section

step.dialogue: [event:count_sections_with_labels]This can be tricky, so let's count together. Watch as I point to each section: one, two, three, four, five. The whole bar has five equal parts. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. You counted all five equal parts.

@metadata.goal: identify and maintain the whole when working with unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Look at these three bars. One shows a single piece that represents [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction].
If that piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction], which bar shows the whole thing?

prompt.text: Click the bar that shows the whole

step.dialogue: Look again. If this is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction], how many pieces make the whole?

events.name: pulse_bar_1
events.description: Bar 1 pulses to show it represents the single piece (1/5)

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_bar_1]You're working on it. [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]One fifth[/fraction] means one piece out of five total. Which bar has five equal pieces?

events.name: highlight_single
events.description: Bar 1 highlights to emphasize it represents one-fifth

events.name: count_sections_sequentially
events.description: Each of the 5 sections in bar 2 lights up sequentially with counting overlay: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

events.name: show_whole_label
events.description: Label appears above bar 2 reading 'The Whole = 5 pieces'

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_single][event:count_sections_sequentially][event:show_whole_label]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. This bar is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction]—one piece. The whole needs five pieces like this. Count with me: this bar has five equal pieces. That's the whole.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]One fifth[/fraction] means one piece out of five total pieces.

@metadata.goal: The student can identify and maintain the whole when working with unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here's a single piece from a rectangle bar. This piece is labeled [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction].
If this one piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction], how many equal pieces make up the whole bar?

prompt.text: Select the number of equal parts in the whole

step.dialogue: Look at the bottom number in the fraction label.

events.name: pulse_label_denominator
events.description: The denominator '6' in the label 1/6 pulses to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_label_denominator]You're working on it. The bottom number in [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] tells you how many equal pieces make the whole. What's the denominator?

events.name: show_whole_reconstruction
events.description: Animation shows the single piece duplicating to form 6 equal pieces arranged as a complete bar, then highlighting that the whole contains 6 parts

events.name: annotate_denominator
events.description: Annotation appears pointing to the '6' in 1/6 with text: 'denominator = total parts in whole'

step.dialogue: [event:show_whole_reconstruction][event:annotate_denominator]Let me show you how this works. This piece is labeled [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. The bottom number—the denominator—is 6. That tells us the whole bar must have 6 equal pieces. This is one of those six pieces. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! The denominator tells you the whole has 6 equal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are two rectangle bars, both the same total size.
Bar A shows [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] shaded. Bar B shows [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction] shaded. Look at the size of each shaded piece.
Which statement is true about these two fractions?

step.dialogue: Look at the actual size of the shaded pieces in each bar.

events.name: highlight_shaded_section
events.description: The shaded sections in both bars pulse to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_shaded_section]Let's think about this together. Compare the shaded sections - which piece takes up more space in its bar?

events.name: measure_shaded_width
events.description: Animated measurement lines showing the width of both shaded sections

events.name: comparison_overlay
events.description: Visual overlay comparing the two shaded sections side by side, showing 1/4 is larger

step.dialogue: [event:measure_shaded_width][event:comparison_overlay]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. Look at Bar A - it's divided into 4 parts, so each part is pretty big. Bar B is divided into 8 parts, so each part is much smaller. The shaded piece in Bar A is larger, so [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] is greater than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. The piece showing [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] is bigger than the piece showing [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction].

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are three rectangle bars. Each bar is divided into equal parts, with one part shaded.
Look at the size of each shaded piece. Which order goes from smallest to largest?

step.dialogue: Look at the actual size of each shaded piece.

events.name: pulse_shaded_section
events.description: Shaded sections of all three bars pulse to draw attention to their sizes

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_shaded_section]Let's think about this together. Compare how much space each shaded piece takes up. Which piece is smallest?

events.name: measure_shaded_width
events.description: Animated measurement lines showing the width of each shaded piece with labels 'smallest', 'medium', and 'largest'

events.name: overlay_ordering_arrows
events.description: Arrows appear showing the correct order from smallest to largest: 1/6 → 1/4 → 1/2

step.dialogue: [event:measure_shaded_width][event:overlay_ordering_arrows]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. Look at the shaded pieces. The [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] piece is smallest because the bar is cut into 6 parts. The [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] piece is medium because it's cut into 4 parts. The [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction] piece is largest because it's only cut into 2 parts. So the order is: [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction], [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction], [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction]. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. You saw that [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] is the smallest piece and [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction] is the largest.

@metadata.goal: The student can apply partitioning strategies and recognize patterns with equal parts

steps.dialogue: Check out these three bars. Each one is divided into equal parts.
Look at the pattern: 2 parts, then 4 parts, then 8 parts. What's happening each time?

step.dialogue: Look at the number of parts in each bar. What changes from one to the next?

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_1
events.description: Bar 1's 2 sections pulse to emphasize count

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_2
events.description: Bar 2's 4 sections pulse to emphasize count

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_3
events.description: Bar 3's 8 sections pulse to emphasize count

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_bar_1][event:pulse_sections_bar_2][event:pulse_sections_bar_3]You're working on it. Count the parts in each bar: 2, then 4, then 8. What's the relationship between these numbers?

events.name: show_count_label_bar_1
events.description: Animated label appears showing '2 parts'

events.name: show_count_and_relationship_bar_2
events.description: Animated label appears showing '4 parts = 2 × 2' with arrow from bar_1

events.name: show_count_and_relationship_bar_3
events.description: Animated label appears showing '8 parts = 4 × 2' with arrow from bar_2

step.dialogue: [event:show_count_label_bar_1][event:show_count_and_relationship_bar_2][event:show_count_and_relationship_bar_3]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Watch the pattern: this bar has 2 parts. The next bar has 4 parts—that's 2 times 2. The last bar has 8 parts—that's 4 times 2. Each time, we're doubling. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: You spotted it. Each bar has double the parts of the one before.

@metadata.goal: The student can apply partitioning strategies and recognize patterns with equal parts

steps.dialogue: Here's a bar divided into 3 equal parts.
Now look at what happens when we divide each third in half. Dotted lines show where the cuts would go.
If you divide each of the 3 parts in half, how many equal parts will you have total?

prompt.text: Select the total number of parts

step.dialogue: Look at the dotted lines. How many sections will there be after the cuts?

events.name: pulse_sections
events.description: Each of the 3 original sections pulses in sequence, then dotted lines pulse to show subdivisions

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections]You're working on it. Count how many parts you start with, then think about what happens when each part is divided in half.

events.name: sequential_subdivision_count
events.description: Animated demonstration: first section highlights and splits (showing '1, 2'), second section highlights and splits (showing '3, 4'), third section highlights and splits (showing '5, 6'), with running count overlay

step.dialogue: [event:sequential_subdivision_count]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. We start with 3 parts. When we divide each part in half, each becomes 2 parts. So 3 times 2 equals 6 total parts. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! Each third splits into 2 parts, giving you 6 total.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are four bars. Some are divided into equal parts, some aren't.
Unit fractions need equal parts. Which bars have all parts exactly the same size?

prompt.text: Select all bars with equal parts

step.dialogue: Look closely at each bar. Are all the parts the same size?

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_a
events.description: All sections of Bar A pulse together to show they are equal

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_c
events.description: All sections of Bar C pulse together to show they are equal

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_bar_a][event:pulse_sections_bar_c]You're working on it. Check each bar carefully - some parts are bigger than others. We need bars where every part matches.

events.name: measure_sections_equal_bar_a
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections are equal width

events.name: measure_sections_unequal_bar_b
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections

events.name: measure_sections_equal_bar_c
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections are equal width

events.name: measure_sections_unequal_bar_d
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_equal_bar_a][event:measure_sections_unequal_bar_b][event:measure_sections_equal_bar_c][event:measure_sections_unequal_bar_d]Let's check each bar together. Bar A - all parts match. Bar B - this part is bigger than that one. Bar C - all parts match. Bar D - these parts are different sizes. So Bar A and Bar C have equal parts.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. You spotted both bars with equal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here's a bar divided into 5 parts. One part is shaded, and someone labeled it [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction].
Look closely at the parts. Is this bar correctly labeled as [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction]?

step.dialogue: Look at the size of each part carefully.

events.name: highlight_sections
events.description: Each section of bar_1 highlights in sequence to draw attention to size differences

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_sections]You're working on it. For fractions to work, all parts must be exactly the same size. Check if these sections match.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal]This is tricky, so let's look together. See how this part is bigger than that part? When parts aren't equal, we can't use fractions. For [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction], all five parts must be exactly the same size. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: You caught it. Equal parts aren't optional - they're required for fractions.

steps.dialogue: Right. For [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction] to work, all five parts need to be the same size. These aren't equal.
